raw_text:
REM announce new Glasgow concert
 
 US band REM have announced plans to perform for 10,000 Scottish fans in a rescheduled gig.
 
 The band will play in what has been dubbed Europe's biggest tent on Glasgow Green on Tuesday, 14 June. They were forced to pull out of a concert at the SECC in Glasgow last month after bassist Mike Mills contracted flu. Fans who bought tickets for the original 22 February show can attend the rescheduled concert. The June gig will act as a warm-up for REM's open air concert at Balloch Castle Country Park, on the banks of Loch Lomond, four days later.
 
 Promoters Regular Music booked Glasgow Green as the SECC was not available on the most suitable date. Mark Mackie, director of Regular Music, said: "It is fantastic news and it really shows REM's commitment to their Scottish fans that they are coming back to Glasgow for what will be a truly unique gig." The REM gigs will kick-start what promises to be a memorable summer for Scottish music lovers.
 
 Grammy Award winners U2 will play Hampden on 21 June while Oasis will also perform at the national stadium in Glasgow on 29 June. Coldplay have announced a concert at Bellahouston Park in Glasgow on 1 July and T in the Park will be held at Balado, near Kinross, from 9-10 July. Ticketweb and the SECC box office will write to customers who bought tickets for the February gig asking if they want to attend the new show. Those who bought tickets in person are being urged to return to the point of purchase. Anyone who cannot make the concert will be given a refund. The cut-off date for swapping tickets is 1 April, when those remaining will go on sale to the public.
llama3.2:1b: REM plans to perform in Glasgow on June 14th at a new venue.
Fans who purchased tickets for their original February show can attend.
The concert will be held at Europe's biggest tent on Glasgow Green.
Promoters booked the venue due to logistical issues.
REM will also play a separate concert at Balloch Castle Country Park on June 18th.
llama3.2:3b: REM announced a rescheduled gig in Glasgow's Europe's biggest tent on June 14, with fans of the original February show able to attend.
The band will play four days before their open-air concert at Balloch Castle Country Park.
Other Scottish music events include U2, Oasis, Coldplay, and T in the Park.
gemma2:2b: REM is rescheduled to perform at Glasgow Green on June 14th for a crowd of 10,000 fans.
This follows the band's cancellation in February due to bassist Mike Mills' illness.
The show serves as a warm-up for their open air concert at Balloch Castle Country Park four days later.
Fans who bought tickets for the original show can attend the rescheduled event.
REM's performance will be followed by U2, Oasis, Coldplay and T in the Park over the following months.
Tickets for the new show will be available through Ticketweb and the SECC box office; refunds will be issued to those unable to attend.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
The Glasgow concert schedule:

- A rescheduled gig for 10,000 Scottish fans in Europe's biggest tent on Scotland's Green.
- Fans who bought tickets for the original 22 February show can attend the rescheduled June gig.
- The June gig will serve as a warm-up for REM's open-air gig at Balloch Castle Country Park on 4 June.
- U2, Oasis, Coldplay, and T in the Park are confirmed to perform their concerts.
- Ticket prices: Regular Music is booking Glasgow Green for Secc for £15; Hampden for £8, Bellahouston Park for £20, and Balado for £30.
qwen2.5:1.5b: REM announce a rescheduled gig at SECC due to bassist illness, featuring other Scottish music acts and promoting upcoming open air shows in Balloch and Bellahouston Parks.
qwen2.5:3b: US band REM has rescheduled their Glasgow gig for June 14 at Glasgow Green, billed as Europe's biggest tent, due to bassist Mike Mills' flu contract last month.
The June show acts as a warm-up for their open-air concert at Balloch Castle Country Park on June 18.
Promoted by Regular Music, the event marks commitment from REM to Scottish fans and sets up an exciting summer of music in Glasgow featuring U2, Oasis, Coldplay, and T in the Park.
Ticket holders can choose between attending the new show or getting a refund; ticket exchanges are due by April 1 for public sale.
opencoder:1.5b: REM announced plans for a new Glasgow concert.
The band has announced plans to perform with 10,000 Scottish fans in a re-scheduled gig.
The concert will be played at Europe's biggest tent on Glasgow Green on Tuesday, June 14.
Fans who bought tickets for the original 22 February show can attend the rescheduled concert.
The June gig acts as a warm-up for REM's open air concert scheduled for Balloch Castle Country Park, near Loch Lomond four days later.
Promoters Regular Music and Grammy Award winners U2, along with Oasis will perform at national stadiums in Glasgow on June 21 and July 29 respectively.
Coldplay announced a concert at Bellahouston Park in Glasgow on 1 July while T will be held at Balado, near Kinross, from 9-10 July.
Ticketweb box office will write to customers who bought tickets for the February gig.
Those who purchased tickets in person will be urged to return to the point of purchase.
Those who cannot make the concert will be given a refund up to 1 April when those remaining on sale to the public.

Here's how you can do it:

1.
Identify the main idea of each paragraph in the text.
In this case, the main idea is that REM have announced plans to perform for 10,000 Scottish fans in a rescheduled gig at Glasgow Green on Tuesday, 14 June.
Determine what key information is essential to understanding the main idea.

The main idea of each paragraph is that:
	* US band REM have announced plans to perform for 10,000 Scottish fans in a rescheduled gig.
* The band will play in Europe's biggest tent on Glasgow Green on Tuesday, 14 June.
* They were forced to pull out of a concert at the SECC in Glasgow last month after bassist Mike Mills contracted flu.
* Fans who bought tickets for the original 22 February show can attend the rescheduled concert.
* The June gig will act as a warm-up for REM's open air concert at Balloch Castle Country Park, on the banks of Loch Lomond, four days later.

* Mark Mackie, director of Regular Music, said: "It is fantastic news and it really shows REM's commitment to their Scottish fans that they are coming back to Glasgow for what will be a truly unique gig."

* Coldplay have announced a concert at Bellahouston Park in Glasgow on 1 July and T in the Park will be held at Balado, near Kinross, from 9-10 July.

* Coldplay have announced a concert at Bellahouston Park in Glasgow on 1 July and T in the Park will be held at Balado, near Kinross, from 9-10 July.
Determine what additional information is not relevant to understanding the main idea.

The main idea of each paragraph is that:
	* The cut-off date for swapping tickets is 1 April, when those remaining will go on sale to the public.
Write a summary of the text concisely, preserving key ideas and details.
The summary should be in plain language, without explanations, no formatting, no reasoning process.

Here's an example:
"Grammy Award winners U2 have announced plans to perform for 10,000 Scottish fans in a rescheduled gig at Glasgow Green on Tuesday, 14 June.
They were forced to pull out of a concert at the SECC in Glasgow last month after bassist Mike Mills contracted flu.
Fans who bought tickets for the original 22 February show can attend the rescheduled concert.
The June gig will act as a warm-up for REM's open air concert at Balloch Castle Country Park, on the banks of Loch Lomond, four days later."
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Rem announced a rescheduled performance at "Europe's biggest tent" on June 14 for 10,000 Scottish fans in Glasgow, forcing them to cancel the original February show at SECC.
Tickets are available now and will serve as a warm-up for Rem's national concert at Balloch Castle four days later.
Promoters from Regular Music highlighted REM's commitment to their fans, stating that it's "fantastic news."
They'll sell tickets online and in venues, with refunds available until April 1 if someone misses the June show.
tinyllama:1.1b: Concert announcement: US band REM have rescheduled their Glasgow concert from February for June, marking the first time that the band has performed in Scotland since their original tour.
The band will perform at Glasgow Green on Tuesday, 14 June, for a capacity audience of over 10,000 people.
Mark Mackie, director of Regular Music booked Glasgow Green as the SECC was not available on the most suitable date for REM's Scottish fans.
The band will be followed by U2, Oasis and Coldplay, who are set to perform at Hampden on 21 June and Balado, near Kinross, respectively, on 1 July.
Ticketweb and the SECC box office will write to customers who have already purchased tickets for the February show asking them to return if they cannot attend the new concert.
Those who do not swap their ticket will receive a refund until the cut-off date of 1 April.
tinydolphin:1.1b: REM announced their intentions to perform at Glasgow's iconic Glaswegian Green on June 14th and invited ticket holders who purchased tickets before the concert was canceled to attend.
The band played a highly successful show in London earlier this month, which has apparently been rescheduled for the same date.

REM's upcoming Glasgow concert will be an incredibly special event that combines an exclusive open-air performance with a warm-up show at Balloch Castle Country Park, where they will perform on Loch Lomond’s banks.
The band's success as a group has always been dependent on their ability to connect with the fans, and this Glasgow concert marks a new chapter in their career.
This summer promises to be an incredibly memorable one for Scottish music lovers, with U2, Coldplay, and Oasis all set to take the stage.
phi:2.7b: US band REM has announced plans to perform in Scotland for 10,000 fans at Europe's biggest tent in Glasgow Green.
The concert was rescheduled after bassist Mike Mills contracted flu and promoters Regular Music booked Glasgow Green as an alternative venue.
The show is part of a summer of music events including U2 and Oasis concerts, and Coldplay and T in the Park performances scheduled for later this year.

They will play what has been titled Europe's biggest tent in a warm-up show for their Balloch Castle Country Park concert the following day.
U2 and Oasis will also perform at Hampden and Bellahouston Park in Glasgow respectively.

Ticketweb and the SECC box office will send letters to customers who bought tickets for the February gig and ask them if they want to attend the new show.
Those who bought tickets in person should return to the point of purchase.
Refunds will be given to anyone who cannot attend.
The cut-off date for swapping tickets is 1 April.

The original concert was canceled due to bassist Mike Mills contracting flu.
Fans who bought tickets for the original event can attend this new performance.

Director of Regular Music, Mark Mackie, expressed REM's commitment to their Scottish fans and mentioned other upcoming concerts in Scotland by U2, Oasis, Coldplay, and T in the Park.
Ticketweb and SECC box office will contact customers regarding ticket options for the February concert, while those who cannot attend will be offered a refund.

stablelm2:1.6b: US band REM has rescheduled a Glasgow concert after bassist Mike Mills contracted flu; they'll perform at Glasgow Green on June 9th, with ticket holders asked if they want to attend the new show or receive a refund.
Grammy winners U2 and Oasis will also play in Scotland this summer.
granite3.1-dense:2b: US band REM has rescheduled their Glasgow concert for Tuesday, 14 June, at Europe's largest tent on Glasgow Green due to bassist Mike Mills' flu.
The event will serve as a warm-up for their outdoor Balloch Castle Country Park show four days later.
Fans who purchased tickets for the February 22 performance can attend the rescheduled gig, with ticket exchanges available until April 1.

Other summer concerts in Scotland include U2 at Hampden on June 21, Oasis on Glasgow's national stadium on June 29, Coldplay at Bellahouston Park on July 1, and T in the Park at Balado from July 9-10.
Ticket refunds are offered for unusable tickets.
